persona.name: David Alan Porter

occupation.title: Lead Carpenter / Crew Lead (Construction and Extraction category)
occupation.organization: Independent subcontractor for a mid-sized residential construction firm (works regularly with two companies in Cobb and Fulton counties)
occupation.description: David works as a lead carpenter and small crew supervisor focusing on single-family home renovations, additions, and new residential framing. He is responsible for: estimating labor hours for jobs; supervising a crew of 2–4 carpenters and helpers; ensuring on-site safety and OSHA compliance; coordinating with homeowners and general contractors on change orders; performing finish carpentry (doors, trim, cabinets) and rough framing; reading blueprints and translating them into actionable day plans; ordering materials and managing small budgets for his crew; training apprentices on best practices and safety. He commonly performs hands-on work (80% of his time) and administrative tasks (20%). He has 18 years of trade experience and a practical, problem-solving approach—good at improvising when a plan fails because houses are rarely perfect squares. He does occasional weekend side jobs (decks, fence repair, small remodels) for extra cash and to keep local relationships strong. He prefers steady work over high-risk bidding and does not engage in office politics. He is non-union but knows many union tradespeople and occasionally subcontracts electricians or HVAC people when required.

persona.residence: Marietta, Cobb County (suburban county outside Atlanta), Georgia, USA
persona.education: Associate of Applied Science, Construction Technology (community college trade program). High school graduate (GED at 18) followed by two years at a technical college. Several industry certificates: OSHA-10, NCCER carpentry credential, forklift operator certificate. Occasional continuing-education classes at the local community college for HVAC basics and blueprint reading.
long_term_goals: Secure financial stability through consistent work and careful saving so he can pay off his mortgage within 10 years.
Maintain and improve his health so he can continue doing physically demanding work into his 60s.
Own a small landscaping shed and workshop behind his house stocked with his favorite tools and a reliable workbench.
Be a reliable presence for his aging parents and siblings; help them when needed without sacrificing his independence.
Build a reputation locally as a dependable subcontractor who finishes jobs on time and stays within budget.
Buy a better pickup (mechanic-friendly, simple, preferably a 1990s–2000s model he can tinker with).
Be active in his church and neighborhood association — serve as a volunteer whenever schedules allow.
Travel once a year to visit a new baseball stadium or attend a college bowl game with a close friend.
Have a quiet, stable retirement with enough savings to avoid burdening family.
Learn to do basic home plumbing and electrical work well enough to reduce service calls.
persona.style: Plain-spoken, direct, and unpretentious. Speaks with a moderate Southern inflection (softened 'r', elongated vowels on certain words) but not heavy drawl; comfortable with colloquial phrasing and occasional profanity among peers. Uses short, practical sentences when working, but will expand into stories when relaxed. Tends to address neighbors and customers politely but informally—'ma'am' and 'sir' sometimes used out of habit. Mannerisms: rubs the back of his neck when thinking, whistles an old country/rock tune while working, taps a pencil when estimating. Moves with the ease of someone used to physical labor—confident and deliberate. Clothing: work boots (worn), Carhartt-style work jacket in winter, plain T-shirts and work jeans, ball cap with local high school logo or pickup brand, safety glasses on the crown of his cap when not working. Keeps his phone on vibrate while working, prefers calls during lunch break or evenings. Communication style: prefers phone calls or in-person conversations for important matters; uses text messages for quick confirmations. In customer interactions, he is warm but pragmatic—will say what he can and won't overpromise. Online behavior: uses Facebook to keep up with old friends and local buy/sell groups; rarely posts about politics but shares church and community event notices. When stressed, becomes quieter and more businesslike; when relaxed, tells stories about projects, sports, or family events.

traits: Conscientious: follows through on commitments and keeps his tools and truck reasonably organized.
Pragmatic: focuses on solving today's problem with the tools at hand rather than theorizing.
Community-oriented: invests time in his church and neighborhood; knows many neighbors by name.
Loyal: stands by longtime friends and employers, expects the same in return.
Reserved emotionally: slow to open up about deep feelings, prefers action over talk.
Sociable in groups: enjoys grilling, sports, and church events—more outgoing in familiar circles.
Competent under pressure: calm when a project hits unexpected issues.
Stubborn: can hold on to his way of doing things and resists changing methods without good reason.
Humorous: dry, self-deprecating humor; enjoys teasing friends but avoids mean-spirited jokes.
Civic-minded: attends community meetings occasionally, cares about neighborhood safety and school funding.
personality.notes_on_big_five: Scores are relative. Openness moderate-low: practical and not prone to abstract theorizing but curious about useful innovations. Conscientiousness high: punctual, reliable, task-focused. Extraversion moderate-high: social within his community and at work. Agreeableness moderately high: cooperative but can be blunt. Neuroticism low-moderate: generally steady, occasional worry about finances or family health.

interests: Home improvement projects: framing, trim, deck building.
College football: follows Georgia Tech and a few SEC teams; attends one game a year.
Baseball: goes to local minor-league games with friends in summer.
Grilling and low-and-slow barbecue techniques—prefers pork shoulder and ribs.
Classic rock and country playlists (70s–90s): Lynyrd Skynyrd, Tom Petty, Chris Stapleton.
Local church activities: potlucks, small-group Bible study on Wednesday nights.
Local hardware stores: likes talking to the counterpeople about new tools.
Vehicle maintenance: enjoys basic mechanical work on his pickup and the occasional engine tune.
Fishing: likes quick weekend trips to the nearby lake, often at dawn.
DIY woodworking for furniture repairs and simple shelves.
Sports radio while driving—station that covers local college football and baseball.
Outdoor socializing: neighborhood block parties, grilling at friends' houses.
Korean and Mexican food for takeout—enjoys flavor and convenience.
Tools and gadgets: battery impact driver, circular saw, framing nailer, multi-bit screwdrivers.
Watching home renovation shows when tired—pays attention to techniques.
Local history and small-town stories—likes hearing about the area’s past.
Budgeting apps on his phone—uses them intermittently to track major expenses.
Occasional hunting with college buddies in the fall.
Listening to podcasts about carpentry techniques and small-business management.
Occasional woodworking projects: a bench, simple cabinets, and a toy box for nieces/nephews.
likes: Coffee in the morning—dark roast, black or with a splash of milk (brewed at home or from a gas station on the way to work).
Simple hearty breakfasts: eggs, bacon, grits or biscuits.
Cold bottled water at job sites and an occasional energy drink on long days.
Locally brewed amber or pale ales on weekend evenings.
Well-fitting work gloves and broken-in boots.
Text confirmations from clients rather than long emails—short and clear.
Neighborhood kids waving at him; he returns the wave.
Christmas gatherings at his parents’ house—he helps with the cooking and cleanup.
A clean, well-organized tool trailer.
Clear, direct criticism: he'd rather be told the truth than placated.
A brisk fall morning for a day of framing—cool, dry weather.
Listening to old baseball broadcast clips for nostalgia.
Company shirts with the crew’s name that he appreciates wearing on busy days.
Small-town diners for late breakfasts—no frills, good coffee, friendly waitstaff.
A job completed and cleaned up before the client returns home.
Weekend mornings to run errands in comfortable jeans and a cap.
A neighbor who returns borrowed tools promptly.
Simple, readable contracts and straightforward invoices.
When apprentices show initiative and learn quickly.
Having enough parts and boards on the truck to avoid a trip to the supplier mid-day.
Occasional charity projects: builds a ramp or fixes a handicap rail pro bono for a neighbor in need.
Spending an hour on a Sunday afternoon mowing his lawn while listening to music.
Watching a baseball game with a small group of friends rather than a big party.
Having predictable, steady schedules rather than constant emergency calls.
Local gas-station breakfast sandwiches as a guilty convenience.
The smell of fresh-cut pine framing lumber on site.
Simple leather wallet, keys with a worn-out Tomcat bottle opener on the ring.
The feeling of a project that 'fits right'—measurements that line up and clean finish work.
Handwritten thank-you notes from satisfied clients—rare but cherished.
dislikes: Overly bureaucratic paperwork that is unclear or redundant.
Clients who micromanage every single small decision without trusting his expertise.
Late payments from customers or slow invoicing.
Weather delays that drag a project into weeks of rain.
Highly theoretical 'design' discussions that ignore practical constraints.
Flimsy or low-quality materials that compromise a job.
City traffic during weekday commutes.
People who take tools without asking and do not return them.
Phone calls in the middle of working on something that requires concentration.
Political rants on Facebook that divide old high-school friends.
High-maintenance, picky clients who change scope constantly.
Needless drama among crew members—prefers issues handled calmly and privately.
Excessive flashy branding or corporate-speak—keeps marketing plain and honest.
Complicated apps that are supposed to save time but add steps instead.
People who don't show up for agreed appointments without notice.
Being told to 'just trust the internet' when a real professional's experience matters.
Extremely expensive coffee—he prefers practical value.
Overly processed frozen dinners—prefers fresh when possible.
Cold, sloppy workmanship on trim details.
Loud, late-night neighbor parties that disturb early mornings.
habits: Checks weather app every morning at 5:45 a.m. before leaving for work.
Takes a thermos of coffee and a sandwich to job sites; sometimes buys lunch out on Fridays.
Does a quick inventory of tools and consumables at the end of each day.
Text-checks with clients around 7 p.m. if he needs to confirm plans for the next day.
Washes his truck roughly once every two weeks; keeps the interior tidy.
Keeps a paper notebook in his truck for measurements and quick sketches.
Calls his mother every Sunday afternoon to catch up.
Fills up gas weekly and always chooses the same station unless there's a sale.
Keeps a small first-aid kit and a bottle of ibuprofen in the truck.
Buys parts from the same lumber and supply store and often chats with the counter staff.
Watches one or two episodes of a non-fiction series before bed to wind down.
Helps a neighbor with odd jobs free of charge roughly once a season as a social obligation.
Maintains a simple Excel spreadsheet for tracking invoices and out-of-pocket expenses.
Sorts tools by type and returns them to designated spots after a job.
Prefers to cash tips or side-job payments immediately and deposit them later the same day.
Uses a single reusable water bottle and a heavy-duty lunchbox.
Gives apprentices a short 10-minute safety talk each morning before work starts.
Listens to the same morning radio program on the way to larger jobs.
Keeps a small stack of business cards and passes them out when asked.
Brings a simple dessert (like a pie from the grocery) to potlucks or church events.

beliefs: Hard work is the baseline of a respectable life—people should provide for themselves where possible.
Homeownership is valuable; it provides stability and pride of ownership.
Safety on the job site matters and protective gear prevents life-changing injuries.
Local community institutions—churches, schools, small businesses—are the backbone of a neighborhood.
You should treat people the way you want to be treated; basic courtesy matters in daily interactions.
There is value in learning a trade; not everyone needs to go to a four-year college to be successful.
Contractors should be honest about timelines and costs; transparency builds long-term business.
People should have access to affordable healthcare, especially for work-related injuries.
Respect for law enforcement officers is important but so is accountability.
It's better to try to fix something yourself (within safety limits) than to waste money unnecessarily.
Religious faith provides community, moral guidance, and practical support during hard times.
Family obligations come first: help aging parents and siblings when they need it.
Taxes are necessary but should be fair and not punitive to small-business owners.
Schools should focus on basic skills—reading, math, civics—and practical career guidance.
Natural disasters and severe weather require prudent preparation and proper insurance.
Immigration should be handled humanely but with sensible rules and enforcement.
Climate change is real but solutions should be pragmatic—focus on efficiency and common-sense conservation rather than panic.
People should take responsibility for their health: eat better, exercise, and get checkups.
Voting is a civic duty; local elections matter as much as national ones.
Guns in rural and suburban life have functional purposes (hunting, defense), but training and safe storage are essential.
Welfare should help those in genuine need but must include accountability and paths to employment.
Technology helps construction (power tools, apps), but experience and hands-on skill remain indispensable.
Public spaces (parks, ballfields) should be kept clean and supported by local budgets.
People in debt should be helped with counseling, but reckless spending should be discouraged.
Contract disputes should be resolved fairly—prefer mediation over prolonged legal battles.
Mental health is important; men should be encouraged to seek help without shame.
Workplace protections like OSHA standards save lives and reduce liability for everyone.
Local businesses deserve patronage over big-box stores when quality and price are comparable.
Volunteering builds social capital and practical networks for future opportunities.
Church involvement is more about community service than doctrinal purity for him personally.
Good mentors in trades are vital—passing skills down matters as much as shutting a crew out.
Minor legal infractions should be treated proportionally—rehabilitation often works better than only punishment.
Pride in craftsmanship matters even on small jobs; attention to detail distinguishes professionals.
He believes in being pragmatic about sustainability: use durable materials to avoid waste.
He thinks that addiction should be treated as a medical and social problem rather than pure criminality.
He believes friendships built around shared activity (work, sports, church) last longer than social media acquaintances.
skills: Framing and structural carpentry: layout, cutting, assembling studs, joists, rafters.
Finish carpentry: trim, casing, baseboards, door hanging and adjustments, simple cabinet finishing.
Blueprint reading and translating plans into on-site action.
Jobsite estimating: labor hours, materials list and basic cost approximation.
Basic concrete work: footings, simple slab patching, setting posts.
Deck building and railing installation according to local codes.
Small-team leadership: scheduling, delegation, on-the-job mentoring.
Basic electrical and plumbing troubleshooting for remodels (knows limits and when to call specialists).
Tool maintenance and small engine repair (mowers, generators): keeps tools in working order.
Safe operation of power tools and light heavy equipment (skid-steer familiarity, articulated lifts exposure).
Welding basics for metal framing or fence repairs (MIG welding for small jobs).
Client communication and managing expectations—clear with job updates and potential delays.
Business basics: invoicing, tracking payments, small-scale budgeting.
Conflict resolution among crew with tact: addresses issues privately and directly.
Basic tile and flooring installation knowledge to coordinate subcontractors effectively.

general: Arrives early to job sites to set up and plan the day's tasks.
Keeps a calm neighborhood persona—greets neighbors and waves to regular drivers.
Puts tools away at the end of the day; dislikes leaving loose nails or trash on site.
Will accept a cold soda or sandwich from a grateful homeowner but rarely asks for extra tips.
When stressed, becomes quieter and focuses on the checklist rather than conversation.
Often hums or whistles while working; it helps him concentrate.
Brings apprentices under his wing—shows them shortcuts learned the hard way.
Does small favors for community members without advertising it; believes in reciprocity.

morning: Wakes around 5:15–5:45 a.m.; quick shower, black coffee, checks weather and texts crew.
Loads truck and inspects tools—battery chargers, saw blades, nails, safety gear.
Arrives at the first site by 6:45–7:30 a.m., depending on job location.
Gives a 5–10 minute safety briefing and assigns tasks to the crew.
workday: Works in 2–3 hour blocks focused on framing, trim, or client-requested tasks.
Takes a 20–30 minute lunch—either brought from home or a nearby diner on Fridays.
Communicates mid-day status to clients when required and orders any missing materials.
Keeps sharp watch on schedules and aligns subcontractors (electricians or plumbers) as needed.
Takes pictures of 'before and after' for his records and client reassurance.
evening: Wraps up and secures the site by 4:30–6:00 p.m., depending on the day.
Cleans tools, refills gas cans, and makes brief notes in his truck notebook.
Spends evenings relaxing: a simple dinner, occasional beers with a neighbor, or a church study night.
Checks bank app or invoices and responds to client texts between 7–8 p.m.
Goes to bed around 10:30–11:30 p.m., later if finishing a project or at a football game.
weekend: Saturday morning often reserved for small side jobs, a church service, or household chores.
Takes a short fishing trip with a friend or visits parents for Sunday lunch.
Works on his own house projects (yard work, small improvement tasks) a few hours on Saturday.
Plays catch with neighborhood kids or helps with a community volunteer build occasionally.
Sunday afternoons are for rest, watching sports, and family check-ins.

physical.general_status: Overall fair health for a 42-year-old who does physical work. Moderately fit from daily labor but not a structured exercise regimen.
physical.weight_and_fitness: Slightly overweight (BMI in upper 20s to low 30s range), visible muscle from work but carries some extra midsection weight.
physical.injuries_and_conditions: Chronic mild lower-back stiffness from years of lifting; occasional flare-ups requiring ibuprofen and heat. Intermittent knee soreness after long framing days. Had a broken wrist at age 24 from a fall on site (fully healed, minor residual stiffness). No major surgeries.
physical.medical_history: No diabetes diagnosis, blood pressure currently slightly elevated during a recent check (borderline high); doctor suggested dietary adjustments and monitoring. Up to date on most routine vaccinations. No known allergies aside from seasonal pollen.
physical.preventive_care: Sees a primary care physician annually and gets bloodwork every 1–2 years. Dental visits twice a year when finances allow (sometimes delayed).
physical.sleep: Typically sleeps 6.5–7.5 hours; sometimes troubled by insomnia when projects or finances are stressful.
physical.substances: Drinks alcohol socially—2–4 beers on weekends, rarely excessive. Smoked cigarettes in his early twenties but quit around age 30. Occasionally uses over-the-counter pain relievers for soreness.
physical.nutrition: Mixed diet: hearty breakfasts, variable lunches (on-the-go), dinners with family or simple takeout. Eats vegetables but tends to prefer meats and starches. Tries to reduce fried foods as he gets older.

mental.general_status: Mentally steady with occasional stress about job consistency, rising costs, and parental health. Generally resilient and optimistic in practical ways.
mental.mood: Usually even-keeled. Experiences short-lived anxiety during financial crunches but no diagnosed anxiety disorder.
mental.support_and_coping: Relies on close friends, church group, and practical problem-solving. Will seek a pastor or friend for counsel; open to counseling if recommended by a trusted person.
mental.history: No history of hospitalizations for mental health. Some bouts of low mood after a breakup (years ago) that improved with time and engagement in work and social activities.

health.healthcare_access: Has employer-based health insurance (basic plan) and supplemental coverage through a spouse? (no — single). Uses local urgent care for minor injuries; has a primary care physician within 15 minutes of his home. Mediates out-of-pocket medical expenses by shopping for generic meds and using community clinic services when needed.

relationships.name: Martha Porter
relationships.description: Lives nearby (20 minutes away). They speak every Sunday; she is a steady emotional support and occasional home-cooked meal provider. He helps her with periodic house maintenance and minor repairs.
relationships.frequency_of_contact: Weekly phone calls; sees in-person 1–2 times/month

relationships.name: Alan Porter Sr.
relationships.description: Retired public-school bus driver. Practical, quiet man who encouraged David's work ethic. David helps with yard work and projects. He and his father share an appreciation for mechanics and local sports.
relationships.frequency_of_contact: In-person once a month; phone as needed

relationships.name: Rebecca (Becky) Sims
relationships.description: Romantically involved years ago; relationship ended amicably. They remain friendly; she lives in Atlanta and they sometimes coordinate on mutual friends and neighborhood events. No children resulted from this relationship.
relationships.frequency_of_contact: Occasional texts and RSVPs to neighborhood events

relationships.name: Marcus Green
relationships.description: Met in trade school and worked together off and on for 15 years. Marcus is the person David calls for urgent second opinions and to grab a beer after long weeks.

relationships.name: Pastor Joel Hernandez
relationships.description: Provides spiritual counsel and community referrals. David respects him and helps with church maintenance projects.
relationships.frequency_of_contact: Weekly church interactions; contact more often for church-related projects

relationships.name: Neighbors at 102 Mulberry Lane
relationships.description: Group of neighbors who look out for each other; David mows driveways and returns favors. He attends block parties and neighborhood watch meetings.
relationships.frequency_of_contact: Several interactions per week (greetings, small favors)

relationships.name: Several local subcontractors (electrician, plumber)
relationships.description: Trusted specialist contacts he calls when jobs require certified work. He exchanges referrals with them and sometimes shares materials orders.

other_facts: Race/ethnicity: White (Non-Hispanic).
Despite being single, he is family-focused—very close to his parents and a handful of cousins who live nearby.
He bought his three-bedroom suburban bungalow five years ago with a 30-year mortgage; he refinanced once when interest rates dipped.
No children and no intention of having any in the near future; he enjoys being able to devote more time to his work and hobbies.
He was the first on his street to volunteer to build the neighborhood mailbox stand and later helped repair it after a storm.
Has a 2003 Ford F-250 with high miles but mechanically reliable—he does routine maintenance himself and likes knowing how it works.
Has a small dedicated tool trailer with his name on a worn sticker; it still smells faintly of oil and pine dust.
Receives a steady stream of referrals from satisfied homeowners and a repeat general contractor who prefers working with him.
Suffered a minor concussion at age 19 when a ladder slipped; he remembers the incident and is cautious at heights now.
Plays on a local amateur softball team in summer; enjoys the social side more than elite competition.
Learnt basic welding from a mentor on his first job in the trade; still uses those skills occasionally.
He once built a ramp pro bono for an elderly neighbor who needed better access—respected in the community for that gesture.
Has a small collection of baseball caps from past projects and sporting events; each has a story attached.
Keeps an emergency fund in a separate savings account and prefers cash-on-hand for unexpected small purchases.
Has a minor blemish in his credit history from a decade ago when a contractor he worked for went bankrupt—resolved but still a memory.
Enjoys telling 'war stories' from early career days when projects went sideways because of rain, bad supplies, or design mistakes.
He did a brief stint helping out at a free community kitchen during a slow season and considers more volunteer service when time allows.
Likes simple rituals: Saturday morning coffee at the same diner and checking the classifieds for used tool deals.
Values practical gifts: a new drill bit set will please him more than novelty items.
Once took a night woodworking class and built a simple rocking chair that now sits in his parents' den.
Knows local inspectors by sight and often exchanges brief professional niceties when pulled for a site inspection.
He is slightly competitive—keeps score at neighborhood cornhole games and doesn't like losing, but laughs it off.
Uses a paper calendar in his kitchen to track big dates: license renewal, insurance payments, and major project milestones.
Remembers co-workers' birthdays and brings donuts to the jobsite occasionally.
Has an old high-school letterman jacket stored in the attic for sentimental reasons—rarely wears it but keeps it for memories.
He once nearly changed careers to fleet mechanics but stayed in carpentry because he liked building tangible progress.
Speaks Spanish at a basic conversational level learned through community interaction; uses it occasionally on jobs with Spanish-speaking subcontractors to coordinate tasks.
He keeps a short list of go-to suppliers who will take back unused materials without fuss—avoids waste and friction when budgets are tight.
Loves lightning storm evenings—remembers childhood nights watching storms and feeling a solemn calm.
Is the unofficial 'fix-it' person for several elderly neighbors who call him when gutters or steps need quick attention.
Has never served in the military but has many friends who did; respects veterans and attends local remembrance events.
Has a small personal library of trade manuals and a shelf of classic sports biographies; reads them when not working late.
Is careful with online reviews—reads them to evaluate potential suppliers and occasionally asks satisfied clients for a good review.
Has changed his diet gradually after a doctor's recommendation: more water, more vegetables at dinner, smaller portions of fried foods.
Keeps a sentimental stack of postcards and notes from clients who were moved by his work—a reminder that his craftsmanship matters.
Was once offered a supervisory position with a large contractor (more money, less hands-on work) and declined because he preferred fieldwork.
Is moderately tech-savvy for his trade: uses a smartphone for client photos, measurements, and quick invoicing but avoids flashy management software that feels overcomplicated.
Has a favorite coffee mug with a faded logo of his old trade school; it's chipped but still in regular use.
Treasure memory: the first house he helped frame that felt 'right'—the family sending him a barbecue invitation after completion left a lasting impression.
He keeps a small notebook of measurement tricks and salvage tips he learned over time; often passes these to apprentices.
Has been recognized by his church with a volunteer award for maintaining the fellowship hall's building for three consecutive years.
Values small-town manners: holds the door for elderly neighbors and returns borrowed ladders the same day.
